awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Secure Near Field Communications between Mobile Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
By the end of this decade, it is estimated that Internet of Things (IoT) could connect as many as 50 billion devices. Near Field Communication (NFC) is considered as a key enabler of IoT. Many useful applications are supported by NFC, including contactless payment, identification, authentication, file exchange, and eHealthcare, etc. However, securing NFC between mobile devices faces great challenges mainly because of severe resource constraints on NFC devices, NFC systems deployed without security, and sophisticated adversaries.

This project investigates three techniques to secure NFC: (1) energy-efficient and fast key agreement mechanisms by exploiting full-duplex capability of NFC devices; (2) RF signal randomization to provide NFC confidentiality without a pre-shared key; and (3) a proximity verification mechanism defending against relay attacks utilizing magnetic sensing. These techniques are expected to significantly improve the key generation rate and reduce energy consumption compared with the conventional Diffie-Hellman key agreement protocol, and achieve high security and usability. These proposed techniques will be evaluated through theoretical analysis, numeric simulation, testbed experiments, and user study, and compared with conventional security mechanisms under different system settings and conditions.

The proposed project will advance research on lightweight, energy-efficient, and usable security mechanisms in mobile networks for IoT applications. The research is applicable to important applications, such as mobile payment and access control. Graduate, undergraduate, minority, and high school students will be actively involved into the proposed research. The newly established Cyber Security Engineering (CYSE) BS program at George Mason University will be enriched through this project. Materials of this project will be made available online in the forms of tutorials, talks, publications, and software toolkits.

por.por_cntn:
The number of handsets shipped with NFC capabilities is set to grow to 2.2 billion by 2020 and the number of NFC enabled items is expected to hit 5 billion over the same period. NFC provides convenient proximity radio communication for many useful IoT applications, including contactless payment, identification, file exchange, and simplified device pairing. Although the communication range of NFC is short, NFC alone does not prevent data modification and eavesdropping. Furthermore, even NFC links can be encrypted, NFC is subject to relay attacks.

To address the security and usability challenges in NFC, the PI has designed and developed the following techniques and mechanisms: 1) energy-efficient and fast key agreement mechanisms by exploiting full-duplex capability of NFC devices; 2) signal randomization and friendly jamming techniques to provide NFC confidentiality without relying on cryptographic encryption; and 3) proximity verification mechanisms defending against relay attacks and supporting secure pairing between NFC devices.

For energy-efficient and fast key agreement between NFC devices, the PI proposed a scheme by exploiting the full-duplex capability of NFC. The proposed method neither requires perfect time synchronization nor absolute match of signal amplitude and phase. It tackles the impact of Gibbs phenomenon. We proved the correctness of the proposed method analytically, and demonstrated its effectiveness by both simulations and experiments. The proposed key agreement method can generate a shared key between two NFC devices at a high rate of about 26 kbps. It is immune to eavesdropping attacks even when the attacker is a few centimeters away from the legitimate users. The energy consumption of the proposed method for generating the same length of key is reduced for at least one order of magnitude compared with the traditional ECDH (Elliptic-curve Diffie–Hellman) protocol. At the same time, the key generation rate is improved by three orders of magnitude.

For secure NFC confidentiality, the PI developed a physical layer approach, SecNFC, to secure inductively-coupled NFC from eavesdropping without relying on cryptographic encryption nor any change to the target devices. Simulation and experimental results demonstrated the effectiveness and security strength of SecNFC. It is immune to MIMO Eavesdroppers and far-field jamming. It can also detect close-by active signal injection and eavesdropping attacks. SecNFC outperforms the state-of-the-art solution, RF-Cloak, in terms of security strength, storage overhead, and energy efficiency. The PI further rebuilt secrecy capacity models and re-evaluated the efficiency of friendly jamming techniques by taking account of micro time scale non-stationary characteristics of transmitting signals. Our reassessments revealed that friendly jamming efficiency is greatly overestimated in the existing literature. An eavesdropper could take advantage of the special waveform structure of the signal to decode legitimate information. Then the PI proposed a new waveform design on jamming signals to enhance the friendly jamming efficiency. The basic idea is to consider both time and frequency domain structure of the transmitting signals and make the time and frequency bandwidth of jamming signals largely match those of transmitting signals. Both simulation and experimental results show that the proposed Time-Fre-Match friendly jamming mechanism can well defend against eavesdroppers employing different decoding methods including constellation based decoding and voltage slope based decoding.

For proximity verification of NFC devices, the PI designed a protocol, MagPairing, to achieve secure NFC device (e.g., smartphone) pairing by using the correlated readings on respective magnetometers equipped on the devices. We implemented the protocol on Android smartphones and conducted extensive experiments to evaluate and validate the proposed protocol. We tackled the challenges of temporal and spatial mis-alignment of the sensing data. Experiments verified that the captured sensor data by MagPairing has high entropy rates. The sensor data information cannot be estimated or forged by a man-in-the-middle attacker even when the attacker is a few centimeters away from smartphones in pairing. Usability tests by untrained users showed that the whole pairing process needs only 4.5 seconds on average with more than 90% success rate. Applicability tests on 3 types of smartphones: Google Nexus 5, GALAXY 3 and MEIZU MX 4 demonstrated that MagPairing is widely applicable to different types of devices and easy to use.

Regarding broader impact, with the support of this project, 4 graduate students including one female student were trained on scientific survey, software defined radio (i.e., USRP) testbed building, experiment running, data analysis, MATLAB simulation, and scientific writing. More than 10 peer-reviewed papers were published in prestigious journals and conferences, including IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, IEEE Wireless Communications, IEEE Network, IEEE Infocom, etc. Three courses related to wireless security are enhanced through the integration of the research results into the course materials. This project built a small-scale NFC testbed. This testbed will be used for senior design projects and open for researchers outside of the PI’s group.
